rename.to: [BUG]  autolog not working from pyspark because of _capture_modules.py stuck

body:
Do you have your minio configuration environment variables set correctly?
Please see: https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#amazon-s3-and-s3-compatible-storage

I'm setting them directly in jupyterlab with these:
os.environ['AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID']=...    
os.environ['AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY']=...
os.environ['MLFLOW_S3_ENDPOINT_URL']=...

They seem to work when logging the pipeline stages (I can find sparkml/metadata and sparkml/stages folders and files  contained  on minio correctly)...

I'm figuring out what is the problem:

the "_capture_modules.py" script creates a new spark context by executing a command "java ....  pyspark-shell"
In my case I'm using a python module to set spark conf and to get a spark session:


```
def get_spark_session(mode="local", jars_path="/usr/local/spark/jars/"): 
  if mode == "kubernetes":
    return _get_client_mode_spark_session(jars_path)  (...)
  else:
    return SparkSession \
          .builder \
          .appName("spark app") \
          .config("spark.jars", ",".join(getJars(jars_path)))\
          .getOrCreate()
```

So I haven't got any 'spark-shell' command  configured.

But the question is: why create a new spark-context/spark-session in that script ? 
Couldn't you make it use the same (already created) spark-context/spark-session we use to log the pipeline?

The `_capture_modules.py` is run as a script from here: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/3f92b645b668e06764bb8ad3c8d1e5ceeb4d97ce/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py#L249-L281
The SparkSession that you're referring to is the subprocess local instance that's just trying to resolve imports in the namespace. 
However, in https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/3f92b645b668e06764bb8ad3c8d1e5ceeb4d97ce/mlflow/utils/requirements_utils.py#L261 the artifact is downloaded from the artifact store (which it seems is the source of the timeout issue that you're seeing). 
We don't use the master SparkSession since we're running this from a subprocess that's isolated from the context that the SparkSession is running in.

and does it need to be isolated necessarily?

When doing log manually, If I use:

conda_env=mlflow.spark.get_default_conda_env()
mlflow.spark.log_model(pipeline_model,"model",conda_env=conda_env)

it works perfectly and if I understand correctly, get_default_conda_env() is doing the same thing, ie collect dependencies

NB: as said in my previous posts, if I omit "conda_env" parameter, there's the same problem.

Thanks for all the answers, BenWilson2. Very kind of you

This does bring up a point about potentially using the current SparkSession. We'll discuss it internally and see if there's a potential change that we could make to this to support your use case (no promises on implementing it; only that we'll discuss it :) )
Yes, thank you. I think it could be a small enhancement for anyone is using spark from jupyterlab with executors on kubernetes

The issue is probably:
https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/3d6827f1775d91bffe401c4dfa57c262eeff7333/mlflow/utils/_capture_modules.py#L115

We should clean 'PYSPARK_GATEWAY_PORT' and 'PYSPARK_GATEWAY_SECRET'  in OSS spark case as well.
Otherwise the child process will try to connect to the spark driver process in parent process, which causes issues.

@seraus Could I ask you to install MLflow on your system from the branch that we just pushed in #6912 to see if this fixes your original issue?
I think this might be a bit faster than trying to recreate the setup that you described that you're running on our end. If this works, we'll get it merged and it will be a part of the next release of MLflow so that you won't have to do any work arounds to get autologging to work in your setup.

i.e.,
```sh
pip install git+https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow.git@clear-pyspark-gateway-for-module-capture
```
and you'll see: "Successfully installed mlflow-1.29.1.dev0" at the conclusion of running this branch install. (Please revert back to an official version afterwards, though!)
Thanks for the directions, I'm assuming is it enough to reinstall the clientapi (module in my conda env of jupyterhub), not the mlflow tracker server. It that so?

same problem, stuck on the launch of the second sparkSession:

```
jovyan    3897  1.5  0.4 584140 110480 ?       Sl   08:24   0:03 /home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/bin/python3.8 /home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mlflow/utils/_capture_modules.py --model-path /tmp/tmp67eg90nw --flavor spark --output-file /tmp/tmpnmikgcim/imported_modules.txt --sys-path ["/home/jovyan/notebook/working", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8/site-packages/git/ext/gitdb", "/tmp/spark-bc9b42e4-055a-475f-8473-e29e2fb226bb/userFiles-2e7fc0d5-d98e-457c-8fdf-7f6ee8f111eb", "/usr/local/spark/python/lib/py4j-0.10.9.3-src.zip", "/usr/local/spark/python", "/home/jovyan/notebook/working", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python38.zip", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8/lib-dynload", "", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8/site-packages", "/home/jovyan/condaenv/edge/lib/python3.8/site-packages/gitdb/ext/smmap"]
jovyan    3906  8.1  1.4 6196092 360928 ?      Sl   08:24   0:15 /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/jre/bin/java -cp /usr/local/spark/conf/:/usr/local/spark/jars/* -Xmx1g -Dio.netty.tryReflectionSetAccessible=true org.apache.spark.deploy.SparkSubmit --conf spark.master=local[1] --conf spark.databricks.io.cache.enabled=False --conf spark.driver.bindAddress=127.0.0.1 --conf spark.python.worker.reuse=True --conf spark.executor.allowSparkContext=true pyspark-shell
```

![cattura-mlflow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41294954/192730000-89284bec-1333-4775-9803-0195ab2548f4.JPG)

@BenWilson2 Would you add log command and let user rerun again ?
https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/6912/files#r982133011

I logged in `__init__`, modified python & log attached
[log.zip](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/files/9663817/log.zip)
Thanks

Could you also test running:

```
        from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
        spark = (
            SparkSession.builder.config("spark.python.worker.reuse", True)
            .config("spark.databricks.io.cache.enabled", False)
            # In Spark 3.1 and above, we need to set this conf explicitly to enable creating
            # a SparkSession on the workers
            .config("spark.executor.allowSparkContext", "true")
            # Binding "spark.driver.bindAddress" to 127.0.0.1 helps avoiding some local hostname
            # related issues (e.g. https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/5733).
            .config("spark.driver.bindAddress", "127.0.0.1")
            .master("local[1]")
            .getOrCreate()
        )
```

on your python environment (Pls start a clean python process to try.) :)

But.. if you look at the exception I reported yesterday, problem doesn't seem to be starting a SparkSession from your code but having it properly configured (in this case it's calling amazon while I have a local minio)
thanks

Caused by: com.amazonaws.thirdparty.apache.http.conn.ConnectTimeoutException: Connect to miniosergio.s3.amazonaws.com:443 [miniosergio.s3.amazonaws.com/52.217.88.84] failed: connect timed out

@seraus I just pushed a change to that branch from earlier that passes the current os.environ values to the subprocess. That PR also has the 'safe' SparkSession creation from within the subprocess for local session creation. Could you try your original code configuration with that branch (uninstall then reinstall MLflow from that branch) and see if it fixes the problem?
